thread.title: Mets could exploit young Cubs lineup: CJ Nitkowski
thread.title_full: Mets could exploit young Cubs lineup: CJ Nitkowski | New York Post

author: Justin Terranova
title: Mets could exploit young Cubs lineup: CJ Nitkowski
text:
Former reliever turned Fox Sports analyst CJ Nitkowski tells The Post’s Justin Terranova why the Cubs’ young lineup could be vulnerable in the NLCS and explains the struggles of David Price as the Blue Jays and Royals square off in the ALCS. 
Q: Any way you would approach a young lineup like the Cubs? 
A: There are a lot of swings and misses in there, but there’s so much power in there that you know if you make a mistake they are going to get it. The approach isn’t that much different. You know you can shoot corners a little bit more, go off the plate a bit more because it is an aggressive team.
Q: Was it a matter of the Cardinals just making too many mistakes in the NLDS? 
A: If you locate well — and picture them going against the Mets or the Dodgers — they have a pretty good chance of silencing those bats. Generally, big swing-and-miss teams, you can shut them down with good pitching in the postseason. We didn’t see that with the Cardinals, but they are a different team than the one we saw in the beginning of the season, especially from a starting-rotation standpoint.
CJ Nitkowski Photo: Fox Sports Q: Who is the favorite in the ALCS? 
A: I don’t think there’s a clear favorite. There’s not one thing to separate: Each team has a strength, each team has a couple of question marks. You can look at both the acquired aces in Johnny Cueto (Royals) and David Price (Blue Jays) as guys who have fallen a little short of expectations. Cueto was great in Game 5 against the Astros, but other than that he’s been a disappointment. Price has been solid in the regular season, but hasn’t really shown up in the postseason, yet. Which one of those guys will be better will have a huge impact on this series.
Q: Why has Price struggled in the postseason? 
A: He’s made some mistakes and he admitted after his first start against the Rangers that he was a little nervous, which surprised me a little bit. It’s kind of hard to believe that he’s been overtaken by the moment and that’s why it hasn’t happened for him, yet. But I think his time is coming. He’s too good of a pitcher to not have success in the postseason. I thought he would do better in Game 1. It appears the Blue Jays liked [Marcus] Stroman a little bit better and planned in that way so he’d start in Game 5 (vs. Rangers), which I found pretty interesting.
Q: Did the Jose Bautista bat flip bother you? 
A: That’s a non-issue for me. We really have a tendency to blow these things out of proportion . Right after the game, it’s emotional and there’s a lot going on. I understand the frustration and people should understand that’s not really a great question to ask after someone just got eliminated from the series. The timing is not right to address the issue.
